Class Logic

java.lang.Object
  Logic

public class Logic
extends java.lang.Object

This is a helper class that contains a series of static methods to assist with the calculating of the color of any given point. The primary formula used in the Mandelbrot set is z(n+1) = z(n)^2 + c, where c is an irrational number that is being tested.

Constructor Summary

          You have no need to instantiate this Object; simply use the static methods provided.

Method Detail

colorTest

public static int colorTest(ComplexNumber c)
The color shader's default testing resolution of 64 iterations per pixel (neatly divisible by 2 to allow for color calculations)

Parameters:
c: - The ComplexNumber that will be tested (of the form ai + b)
Returns:
the number of iterations it takes until escape, or -1 otherwise if it doesn't within 64 iterations.

colorTest

public static int colorTest(ComplexNumber c,
                            int numIterations)
The basic tester for anything that uses color. Similar to the greyscale logic, but used for anything that requires color.

Parameters:
c: - The ComplexNumber that will be tested (of the form ai + b)
numIterations: - How many iterations will be tested for (usually a multiple of 8 to make color calculations easier)
Returns:
How many iterations it takes for the tested number to escape, or -1 if it does not in the given amount.

greyTest

public static boolean greyTest(ComplexNumber c)
The default shader's default testing resolution of 100 iterations per pixel.

Parameters:
c: - The ComplexNumber that will be tested (of the form ai + b)
Returns:
true if this number doesn't go to infinity within 100 iterations, false otherwise.

greyTest

public static boolean greyTest(ComplexNumber c,
                               int numIterations)
The default shader's default logic; Does a given amount of iterations on the given number.

Parameters:
c: - The ComplexNumber that will be tested (of the form ai + b)
numIterations: - How many iterations will be tested for.
Returns:
true if this number does not go to infinity in the given number of iterations, false otherwise.
